Title.evidence: Background: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are widely used in surgery.

Trial_Design.evidence: The retrospective study was performed to explore the efficacy of intraoperative NSAIDs on postoperative pulmonary complications (PPCs) in patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) after surgery.

Participants.evidence: Patients with NSCLC who underwent lung resection between January 1 and May 31, 2019, were included in this study.

Intervention.evidence: Patients who were given NSAIDs were assigned to the NSAIDs group, while patients who did not receive NSAIDs were assigned to the control group.

Objective.evidence: The retrospective study was performed to explore the efficacy of intraoperative NSAIDs on postoperative pulmonary complications (PPCs) in patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) after surgery.

Number_Randomised.evidence: In the study, 139 patients received perioperative NSAIDs, while 167 patients did not.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Propensity score-matched analysis created a matched cohort of 238 patients, with 119 patients in each group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: After matching, the frequencies of postoperative pneumonia, respiratory failure, and myocardial ischemia were significantly lower in the NSAIDs group than those in the control group (P<0.05).
